titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Geneva Valentine papers, 1922-2008 MS2340
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-18 12:02:49 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: This collection contains correspondence, personal writing, publications, legal and financial documents, memoranda, meeting minutes, memorabilia, photographs, scrapbooks, negatives, yearbooks, and company records documenting the activities of businesswoman, realtor, and Washington DC community leader Geneva K. Valentine. These materials date from 1922 to 2008 since they include records of family members and family-run corporations in addition to the records of Mrs. Valentine. The bulk of the collection dates between 1922 and 1987.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Geneva Kent Valentine (1901-1971), a prominent businesswoman and community leader in Washington, DC, was the first African-American to gain membership in the National Association of Real Estate Boards, among many other achievements. Mrs. Valentine was born in Northumberland County, Virginia on August 15, 1901. She graduated from Washington DC's Dunbar High School in 1922, and graduated from Hartshorn Memorial College's Normal School in Richmond, Virginia before attending law school at American Uniersity. Mrs. Valentine worked as a secretary before going into business. She was president of Equitable Realty Co. (which she helped found in 1931) and managed several other companies in addition to her real estate career, including the first Western Union branch on the east coast to be owned by an African-American.

Mrs. Valentine was well-known as a civic leader in professional clubs and local organizations who demonstrated significant involvement in causes related to education, housing, and urban poverty. She served as National President of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs and was a member of the Century Club. She contributed to community initiatives as President of the Adams-Morgan Federation and an organizer of Positive Action Against Crime, as well as through the events and services she helped provide at Inspiration House (a black cultural center), the Guy T.O. Hollyday House (a community revitalization and redevelopment organization), and her work on education and library resources through the M.C. Terrell Fund. She also worked with the Mayor's Economic Development Committee on initiatives to foster police-community relations.

Mrs. Valentine was highly involved in Civil Rights movements through the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights and her efforts as Legislative Chairman of the national Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs. Her opinions have been solicited regarding Civil Rights legislation, and the organizations with which she was involved prepared reports and commentaries on these issues. Mrs. Valentine was a registered Republican and served as Chairman of the Assembly of Women's Organizations for National Security. She has corresponded with Civil Rights activist A. Philip Randolph, DC's Mayor Walter E. Washington, U.S. Senators including Edward Kennedy and Gaylord Nelson, Secretary of State Dean Rusk, President Richard Nixon, and other ambassadors, dignitaries, and high-ranking officials. She met with former First Lady Mamie Eisenhower, and entertained prominent individuals such as Lady Astor, whom she met at the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.
Geneva Valentine died in Washington, DC on April 10, 1971.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the correspondence, personal writings, resumes, address books, notes, meeting minutes, speeches, legal documents, tax files, financial records, reports, programs, memoranda, brochures, awards, certificates, magazines, newspaper clippings, photographs, yearbooks, scrapbooks, and travel memorabilia of Geneva K. Valentine and the organizations of which she was a part. The collection also contains records of some of Mrs. Valentine's family members, primarily her husband Hugh Valentine, Sr. and son Hugh Valentine, Jr. The bulk of the material dates from 1923-1987.The material in this collection covers Mrs. Valentine's history as a businesswoman, her contributions to the Washington, DC community in the areas of equal housing, alleviation of poverty, and crime prevention, and her advocacy at a national level for Civil Rights and desegregation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 6 series: Biographical information and personal materials; Photographs, yearbooks, and scrapbooks; Clubs and associations; Business and financial records; Community, political, and legislative engagement; and Family members of Geneva Valentine.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Donor represents and warrants that the Donor owns and wishes to retain the Donor's copyright rights in and to the Collection for a period of five (5) years starting March 17, 2015. On March 20, 2020, the Donor hereby assigns to the Library the entire right, title and interest in and to all copyright rights in the Collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this series include biographical information about Geneva Valentine including two obituaries and a eulogy, as well as original works and writings she produced, such as poertry, memoir chapters, speeches, invention blueprints, resumes, and correspondence. This series also includes travel records from a trip to Nashville and a European tour for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, where Mrs. Valentine met with delegates and ambassadors and was interviewed by the BBC due to her role as National President of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs. Additionally, this series contains magazines, recipes, hospitality and etiquette guides, newspaper clippings, address books, handwritten notes, awards, and certificates belonging to Geneva Valentine. The materials in this series range in date from circa 1923 to Mrs. Valentine's death in 1971, and have been arranged from most to least proximity to Mrs. Valentine. Publications have been arranged chronologically where possible.

The chapters of Mrs. Valentine's memoir are accompanied by editorial commentary and estimates for publishing fees. Her memoir and poetry cover topics such as family history, personal heartbreak, religion, and professional struggles and successes. Her obituary suggests that these documents had been delivered to publishers but not yet printed at the time of her death.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged by material type, chronologically where possible.

did.unittitle: Eulogy and obituaries for Geneva Valentine

odd.head: General
odd.p: This certificate has been ripped into two pieces and is crumpled to the point where it is impossible to open. Most likely needs preservation attention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series include photographs, scrapbooks, and yearbooks of Geneva Valentine, her family, her 1953 trip to Europe, and the organizations of which she was a part, including the Century Club and the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs. They range in date from Mrs. Valentine's 1922 high school yearbook through the 1960s, with one photograph from 2008 found in a scrapbook of materials pertaining to Hugh Valentine Jr. The series is organized such that scrapbooks, photo albums, the baby book of Geneva's daughter Jeanne, and other bound collections of photographs are first in the series, followed by individual images or smaller groups in roughly chronological order. This series also contains one folder of negatives, one folder of photocopied images, and several flat boxes of oversize scrapbooks and portraits.

The images and ephemera in this series provide visual insight into areas of Mrs. Valentine's life and work, with subjects including the family and its cat, houses and construction, social and professional functions, honorees of awards, community spaces such as Inspiration House, and a photograph of Mrs. Valentine meeting former First Lady Mamie Eisenhower.

Photographs for Pause and Acclaim event

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this series include correspondence, minutes, speeches, newsletters, reports, publications, event planning documents, photographs, and membership records of the Century Club, the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs, and other social and professional organizations to which Geneva Valentine belonged, including the Iota Phi Lambda sorority. They primarily range in date from the 1940s through the 1970s, with some publications dating as late as 1984. The series is arranged alphabetically by organization where possible.

In her role as National President of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Mrs. Valentine traveled to Europe for the 1953 coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, and served as a delegate at the White House Conference on Aging in 1963. She has also been featured in multiple issues of Responsibility, the official magazine of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs. Mrs. Valentine (and the organizations with which she was involved) planned and sponsored fundraisers and events that supported various community initiatives, including education and scholarships for young women.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this series include correspondence, financial records, minutes, incorporation documents, deeds, leases, land survey maps, and other records pertaining to the real estate companies and other corporations Geneva Valentine and her immediate family members owned, managed, or substantially interacted with. These organizations include 2008 16th Street, Inc., the Arundel Ridge Corporation, the Clinton and Valentine Development Corporation, Equitable Realty Company, Orbital Properties, Inc., Tidewater Developing Corporation, Valentine Realty, Western Union, and Hamburger Grill. Some of these companies remained under family ownership after Mrs. Valentine's death, therefore the records in this series date from 1939 to 1987. This series also contains income tax records, financial documents, reports from Mrs. Valentine's time as a notary public, lawsuit documentation and statements, court summons, and other legal records of Geneva Valentine and other individuals.
The materials for businesses in this series are arranged alphabetically by organization where possible, followed by financial documents arranged by proximity to Mrs. Valentine, and legal documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this series include correspondence, memoranda, newsletters, financial documents, meeting minutes, reports, publications, and event planning documents pertaining to Mrs. Valentine's involvement in Washington, DC community organizations as well as national political and legislative initiatives. This series ranges in date from 1948 to 1971and is arranged with community organizations first in alphabetical order where possible, followed by documents pertaining to national political and legislative initiatives. The community initiatives and organizations documented in this series include the Adams-Morgan Federation (of which Mrs. Valentine served as president until the time of her death), the Beautification Committee for Adams-Morgan, Asbury Methodist Church, the Guy T.O. Hollyday House, Inspiration House, Housing and Urban Development-related initiatives, Positive Action Against Crime (a group which Mrs. Valentine helped organize), the Mayor's Economic Development Committee, the Mary Church Terrell Fund, and Metrorail.

Through her involvement with the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, the Natinal Urban League, the Urban Coalition, the DC Women's Anti-Crime Crusade, and her position as Legislative Chairman of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Mrs. Valentine advocated for anti-violence, alleviation of urban poverty, crime prevention, housing and education issues, as well as Civil Rights legislation and desegregation initiatives, and "Defense Against Communism," a subject about which Mrs. Valentine helped publish a fact sheet as part of her leadership in the Assembly of Women's Organizations for National Security. She also corresponded with organizations such as Planned Parenthood to work on health and family planning-related initiatives.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by organization, then by subject area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this series pertain to members of Geneva Valentine's family, namely her husband Hugh Valentine, Sr. and her son, Hugh Valentine, Jr. This series dates from 1940 to 1987 and includes financial documents and calculations, income tax forms, deeds, legal documents(including Hugh Valentine, Jr.'s marriage and divorce paperwork), correspondence, and real estate documents (including records of 2008 16th Street Inc. dating beyond Geneva Valentine's death). Also included in this series is a Resolution of Appreciation to Hugh Valentine Sr. from the National Geographic Society. This series is organized as close to chronologically as the original order and arragnements of its materials would allow. The papers of Hugh Valentine, Sr. are followed by the papers of Hugh Valentine, Jr.

did.unittitle: Hugh Valentine Sr. Papers: Resolution of Appreciation to Hugh Valentine from National Geographic Society

odd.head: General
odd.p: Item is housed in Series 1, Box 5 with other oversize certificates
